page.title: 01Wallasey- an overview
page.content: Burdett's map circa 1797(i) shows (Wallasey) as a small village forming one corner of a triangle;the other two corners made up by{Liscard}to the west and{Poulton}to the south.South again of Poulton is{Wallasey Pool}, effectively cutting those three villages off from the rest of{Wirral}. Today,the area is served by a {Motorway,the M53}and has both rail and road links to other Wirral areas; a{Ferry}and the most recent{Road {Tunnel}provide a service to connect travellers with{Liverpool}and the North.In fact,{Poulton Bridge}, situated close to{Bird House},the oldest inhabited building in Wallasey, is still known as{"The Penny Bridge" and has been a crossing point for many years.Other road connections are by {Duke Street Bridge}and{"Four Bridges"} All these bridges are subject to {
